instruction: Can visible near infrared hyperspectroscopy (VNIH) and deep learning tools be considered superior to traditional methods in accurately identifying the khapra beetle from other closely related Trogoderma species, particularly in the larval stage?
Output: Yes, visible near infrared hyperspectroscopy (VNIH) and deep learning tools can be considered superior to traditional methods in accurately identifying the khapra beetle from other closely related Trogoderma species, particularly in the larval stage. The study used VNIH imaging technology coupled with deep learning models, specifically Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and Capsule Network, to analyze hyperspectral images of different Trogoderma species and their various life stages. The results showed that both models achieved an overall accuracy of over 90%, with the Capsule Network achieving a higher accuracy of 96%. This indicates that VNIH and deep learning tools can effectively differentiate the khapra beetle from other morphologically similar Trogoderma species, even in the larval stage. Additionally, the technology offers the possibility of identifying Trogoderma species from body fragments and larvae skins, which are otherwise impossible to diagnose taxonomically.
